questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 2-week history of abnormal behavior. The patient has not slept in over a week and has been partying each night. He has never done this before. The patient has also been skipping work and purchased a car last week with money they had saved for their vacation to Italy. Medical history is remarkable for major depressive disorder and type 1 diabetes mellitus poorly controlled with insulin. He normally drinks one or two beers on weekends but has been drinking 6–10 beers per day for the past week. He appears agitated and is wearing brightly-colored, mismatched clothing. His temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, his speech is pressured and his thought process is tangential. A complete blood count, serum electrolytes, and liver enzyme activities are within the reference range; his serum creatinine is 1.8 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows 2+ proteinuria and WBC casts. Toxicology screening is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate long-term management for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dialectical behavior therapy is a form of cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT). In patients with bipolar disorder, CBT can be used after the remission of an acute manic episode as an adjunct to help the patient avoid stressors that could trigger a relapse of acute mania, as an adjunct to treat depressive episodes that are not controlled by maintenance therapy, and as a tool to increase patient compliance and follow-up. CBT is, however, not effective as stand-alone maintenance therapy in preventing acute manic episodes.

Dialectical behavioral therapy is the treatment of choice for patients with borderline personality disorder (BPD). Patients with BPD may have some of the features of bipolar disorders such as an unstable mood and impulsivity. However, unlike in patients with bipolar disorder in whom mood swings (mania, hypomania, depression) develop slowly and lasts several days to weeks, the mood swings in BPD are transient (usually a few hours to days) and occur rapidly in reaction to situational or environmental triggers. Also, BPD is more common among women and includes other features such as intense but labile relationships, suicidal ideation or attempts at self-harm, fear of abandonment, an unstable self-image, aggression, and/or stress-related paranoia.

B) CORRECT:

Sodium valproate is a mood stabilizer that is used as maintenance therapy following a manic episode in patients with bipolar disorder. Mood stabilizers treat and prevent episodes of acute mania, hypomania, and depression and reduce the risk of relapse, self-harm, and suicide. Effective treatment of bipolar disorder combines pharmacological therapy with psychological interventions.

Although lithium is the preferred mood stabilizer for bipolar disorder, it is contraindicated in patients with features that suggest renal dysfunction, such as this patient with elevated serum creatinine levels and proteinuria (likely due to diabetic nephropathy).

C) INCORRECT:

Atypical antipsychotics (e.g., olanzapine) can be used as monotherapy for the acute treatment of hypomania or mild to moderate mania in patients with bipolar disorder, or in combination with another form of therapy in patients with severe mania. However, antipsychotic monotherapy is less effective at preventing relapses and has greater side effects (e.g., severe weight gain, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia) than other maintenance therapies. A different long-term management option is more appropriate for this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Benzodiazepines (e.g., clonazepam) can be used as an adjunct in the management of agitation in acute manic episodes. However, benzodiazepines are not recommended as maintenance therapy for bipolar disorder because there is no evidence that they are effective in preventing relapses. Moreover, long-term therapy with benzodiazepines carries the risk of dependence.

E) INCORRECT:

Lithium is the preferred drug for maintenance therapy in patients with bipolar disorder and is also used to manage manic episodes in this condition. However, lithium is contraindicated in patients with renal dysfunction, such as this patient with elevated serum creatinine levels and proteinuria (likely due to diabetic nephropathy), because it is eliminated by the kidneys and has a narrow therapeutic index. An increase in the levels of lithium above the therapeutic window can result in serious adverse effects like nephrotoxicity and thyrotoxicity.

F) INCORRECT:

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (e.g., escitalopram) can be used to treat severe depression in bipolar disorder or predominantly depressive bipolar II disorder after patients have been started on first-line maintenance therapy. Antidepressants should not, however, be used as monotherapy in bipolar disorder because of the increased risk of triggering manic episodes.
questions.hint: This patient's signs and symptoms are consistent with bipolar disorder manifesting with acute mania.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her parents because of an irritable mood that started 5 days ago. Since then, she has been staying up late at night working on an art project. She is enrolled in community college and has been able to complete her daily schoolwork and look after her younger brother at home without issues. She feels rested despite sleeping less than 4 hours per night. Her parents also report that she seems easily distracted and more talkative than usual. She has never had similar symptoms before. In the past, she has had episodes where she felt too tired to go to school and slept until 2 PM every day for 2 weeks at a time. During those episodes, her parents noticed that she cried excessively, was very indecisive, and expressed feelings of worthlessness. She has a history of asthma controlled with inhaled albuterol as needed. Two months ago, she developed a mild exacerbation that was managed with inhaled albuterol and oral prednisone. She tried cocaine once in high school but has not used it since. Vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, she is irritable but cooperative. When asked how she feels, the patient says, “I feel great. I'm not sure why I even need to see a doctor.” Her speech is pressured, and her thought process is linear. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Bipolar II disorder is a subtype of bipolar disorder that is characterized by hypomania and major depression. The distinction between hypomania and mania depends on the intensity and duration of manic symptoms. Hypomania is characterized by manic symptoms (e.g., irritable mood, goal-directed behavior, decreased need for sleep, distractibility, and increased talkativeness in this patient) for ≥ 4 days without significant functional impairment. This patient's hypomania in combination with past major depressive episodes (i.e., excessive fatigue, depressed mood, indecisiveness, and feelings of worthlessness that lasted ≥ 2 weeks) fulfill the criteria for bipolar II disorder.

B) INCORRECT:

Bipolar I disorder is a subtype of bipolar disorder that is characterized by at least one manic episode that lasts ≥ 1 week with or without major depressive episodes. Manic episodes cause significant functional (e.g., occupational or social) impairment, often requiring hospitalization, and psychotic features may be present. Although this patient has some manic symptoms (irritable mood, goal-directed behavior, decreased need for sleep, distractibility, increased talkativeness), they are not severe enough to cause significant impairment; she is able to complete her daily schoolwork and look after her younger brother at home without issues.

C) INCORRECT:

Major depressive disorder (MDD) is characterized by ≥ 5 depressive symptoms, one of which must be depressed mood or anhedonia, for a period of ≥ 2 weeks. This patient's 2-week periods of tearfulness, fatigue/low energy, hypersomnia, indecisiveness (i.e., impacted cognition), and feelings of worthlessness (i.e., guilt) are part of SIGECAPS and fulfill the clinical criteria for major depressive disorder. However, in addition to her depressive episodes, she also exhibits goal-directed behavior, decreased need for sleep, distractibility, and increased talkativeness, which are inconsistent with MDD.

D) INCORRECT:

Schizoaffective disorder is characterized by the presence of psychotic symptoms with a concurrent mood disorder (e.g., major depressive disorder or bipolar disorder). Although this patient meets the clinical criteria for major depressive disorder (e.g., 2-week periods of tearfulness, fatigue/low energy, hypersomnia, indecisiveness, and feelings of worthlessness), she does not have psychotic symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients who use stimulant drugs, such as cocaine and methamphetamine, can develop manic symptoms followed by depression. Although this patient has a history of cocaine use, she has not used it since high school and shows no characteristic findings of stimulant use (e.g., tachycardia, hypertension, mydriasis), making this diagnosis unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

Cyclothymia is a milder variant of bipolar disorder in which an individual's mood swings between hypomania and depression, but episodes are not severe enough to establish a diagnosis of bipolar I or bipolar II disorder. Although this patient's hypomanic symptoms are a component of cyclothymia, her depressive symptoms are too severe. Her 2-week periods of tearfulness, fatigue/low energy, hypersomnia, indecisiveness (i.e., impacted cognition), and feelings of worthlessness (i.e., guilt) are part of SIGECAPS and fulfill the clinical criteria for major depressive disorder.

G) INCORRECT:

The patient was treated with steroids 2 months ago for an asthma exacerbation. Steroid-induced mania can be seen within days to a few weeks after starting corticosteroid therapy. These symptoms resolve within weeks of discontinuing therapy. This patient has not been using steroids since her asthma exacerbation, and the medication should not be affecting her now.
questions.hint: Monotherapy with quetiapine is a first-line treatment option for this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband, who is concerned about her ability to care for herself. Three weeks ago, she quit her marketing job to start a clothing company. Since then, she has not slept more than 4 hours per night because she has been working on her business plans. She used a significant portion of their savings to fund business trips to Switzerland in order to buy “only the best quality fabrics in the world.” She has not showered and has eaten little during the past 3 days. She had 2 similar episodes a few years ago that required hospitalization and treatment in a psychiatry facility. She has also experienced periods of depression. She is not currently taking any medications and uses a copper intrauterine device for contraception. She appears unkempt and agitated while pacing up and down the room. She speaks very quickly about her business ideas, without pausing. She has no suicidal ideation or thoughts of self-harm. Results of laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. Urine toxicology screening is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for the management of this patient?

choices.text: Valproic acid therapy for one year

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Risperidone is not a first-line agent for bipolar disorder. Since this patient has not yet trialed a first-line mood stabilizer, risperidone is not indicated at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Benzodiazepines, such as clonazepam, can help control acute symptoms of mania (agitation, restlessness) but are not effective in the treatment of an underlying bipolar disorder. Furthermore, long-term use of benzodiazepines is not recommended due to the potential for addiction.

C) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid can be an effective treatment for acute mania and for preventing relapse of mania in patients with bipolar disorder and diminished kidney function. However, maintenance therapy should be administered for decades or even lifelong. This patient with no history of kidney disease and three separate manic episodes (which warrants long-term treatment) should be given medication with a better side-effect profile for more than just one year.

D) INCORRECT:

Due to its risk of severe neutropenia, clozapine therapy is reserved for patients with schizophrenia in whom other antipsychotic drugs have proven ineffective. Clozapine has no role in the treatment of bipolar disorder.

E) INCORRECT:

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) monotherapy, such as with sertraline, should be avoided in patients with bipolar disorder due to the potential risk of precipitating a manic episode. SSRI dual therapy with a mood stabilizer or second-generation antipsychotic can be considered for patients with bipolar disorder and comorbid major depressive disorder. Currently, however, this patient has no depressive symptoms (e.g., depressed mood, anhedonia, feeling of worthlessness) and does not require SSRI therapy at this time.

F) CORRECT:

Long-term maintenance therapy is recommended for bipolar disorder because it is a condition with a high degree of recurrence. Maintenance pharmacotherapy reduces the risk of disease relapse, self-harm, and suicide. Lithium is the preferred first-line treatment, but the same regimen that successfully treated the acute episode is usually continued as maintenance therapy. Kidney function must be assessed prior to initiating therapy as lithium is renally excreted. Because lithium has a narrow therapeutic index, lithium blood levels must be checked regularly. Women of childbearing age should be offered contraception and counseled that lithium is potentially teratogenic. If a patient is pregnant or wishes to become pregnant, other treatment options should be considered.
questions.hint: This patient presents with elevated and expansive mood, increased goal-directed behavior lasting most of the day for more than 1 week, pressured speech, and decreased need for sleep, all of which are concerning for a manic episode (see “DIG FAST”). Considering her additional history of depression, she most likely suffers from bipolar disorder, which is initially treated with a mood stabilizer.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by police officers due to inappropriate public behavior. He was at a pharmacy demanding to speak with the manager so he could discuss a business deal. Two weeks ago, he left his wife of 10 years and moved from another city in order to pursue his dreams of being an entrepreneur. He has not slept for more than 3-4 hours a night in the last 2 weeks. He has a history of bipolar disorder and diabetes. He has been hospitalized three times in the last year for mood instability. Current medications include lithium and insulin. Mental status examination shows accelerated speech with flight of ideas. His serum creatinine concentration is 2.5 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carbamazepine by itself would probably not be a sufficient treatment for this patient. While this antiepileptic agent usually can be used alternatively to lithium for maintenance therapy in bipolar disorder, this patient is refractory to monotherapy with lithium and now needs a more intensive therapy for long-term management.

B) INCORRECT:

Clozapine is not indicated for the management of bipolar disorder. It is typically used for refractory schizophrenia.

C) INCORRECT:

While lithium and valproic acid can be given concurrently in patients with bipolar disorder, this combination is not indicated in this patient, as his renal failure is a contraindication for continued use of lithium.

D) CORRECT:

Combination therapy with a mood stabilizer (e.g., valproic acid) and an antipsychotic (e.g., quetiapine) is a first-line therapy option for maintenance treatment of refractory or severe bipolar disorder. The goal of maintenance therapy is to prevent future manic and depressive episodes and to reduce the risk of suicide. This actively manic patient with three hospitalizations within the last year has been refractory to monotherapy with the mood stabilizer lithium, and requires additional pharmaceutical management. In this case, lithium should be switched to a different mood stabilizer (i.e., valproic acid) as his labs indicate renal failure, which is a contraindication to lithium use. Further contraindications to lithium include severe dehydration, severe hyponatremia, and significant cardiovascular disease.

E) INCORRECT:

A combination of lithium and olanzapine would not be appropriate for this patient. While a combination therapy of a mood stabilizer and an antipsychotic is first-line therapy for the maintenance treatment of refractory or severe bipolar episodes, this patient's renal failure is a contraindication for continued use of lithium.
questions.hint: This patient with refractory bipolar disorder (i.e., accelerated speech with flight of ideas and decreased need for sleep despite lithium therapy) is presenting with an acute manic episode and has significant renal dysfunction (serum creatinine > 1.5 times baseline).

questions.text: A 29-year-old man comes to the physician with his wife because she has noticed a change in his behavior over the past 2 weeks. His wife reports that he is very distracted and irritable. His colleagues have voiced concerns that he has not been turning up for work regularly and behaves erratically when he does. Previously, her husband had been a reliable and reasonable person. The patient says that he feels “fantastic”; he only needs 4 hours of sleep each night and wakes up cheerful and full of energy each morning. He thinks that his wife is overreacting. The patient has been healthy except for a major depressive episode 5 years ago that was treated with paroxetine. He currently takes no medications. His pulse is 98/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 128/62 mm Hg. Mental status examination shows frenzied speech and flight of ideas. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Male gender is not associated with an increased risk of developing bipolar disorder. Although women do have an increased risk of relapses and are more inclined to have rapid cycling mood disorder, a subtype of bipolar disorder, there is no gender difference in the incidence of bipolar disorder.

B) INCORRECT:

Obstetric complications affecting the mother do not appear to be associated with the pathogenesis of bipolar disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

Although higher socioeconomic class has been associated with an increased incidence of bipolar disorder, recent studies were unable to confirm this association and it is not the strongest predisposing factor.

D) INCORRECT:

Studies have shown that bipolar disorder occurs more commonly in patients with traumatic experiences in childhood. Other studies have indicated an increased risk of early onset or severe courses of bipolar disorder in patients who experience emotional or sexual abuse in their childhood. However, the degree to which these experiences influence the pathogenesis of the disorder is unclear, and another factor is more significant.

E) INCORRECT:

Advanced paternal age is associated with an increased risk of mutations during spermatogenesis. Studies show increased rates of bipolar disorder in the offspring of fathers of advanced age. However, it is not the strongest predisposing factor.

F) CORRECT:

Genetic predisposition is the strongest predisposing factor for bipolar disorder. While the lifetime risk of developing bipolar disorder is ∼ 2% in the general population, a first-degree relative of an individual with bipolar disorder has a lifetime risk of up to 10%. Those who have a monozygotic twin with bipolar disorder have a lifetime risk of up to 70%.

G) INCORRECT:

Stressful life events can trigger episodes of bipolar disorder. Studies also indicate that stressful life events increase the risk of early onset and severe courses of disease. However, they appear to increase the risk of recurrence rather than new onset of bipolar disorder and are therefore not the strongest predisposing factor.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a 2-week history of elevated and irritable mood, decreased need for sleep, frenzied speech, and flight of ideas. Together, these features fulfill the diagnostic criteria for acute mania and consequently bipolar I disorder.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her roommate because of unusual behavior and incoherent talkativeness for the past week. Her roommate reports that the patient has been rearranging the furniture in her room at night and has ordered a variety of expensive clothes online. The patient says she feels “better than ever” and has a lot of energy. She had a depressive episode 1 year ago. She had absence seizures as a child and remembers that valproate was discontinued because it damaged her liver. She takes no medication. She is sexually active with her boyfriend. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Physical and neurologic examinations show no abnormalities. Her pulse is 78/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 122/60 mm Hg. Mental status examination shows lack of insight, affective lability, and pressured speech with flight of ideas. Urine toxicology screening is negative. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Prior to prescribing long-term pharmacotherapy for this patient, it is most appropriate to obtain which of the following additional tests?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum transaminases are a side effect of valproate, which is used as long-term treatment for bipolar disorder and as first-line therapy for acute mania in bipolar disorder. Liver function tests should be performed prior to and throughout treatment with valproate. Given this patient's history of valproate-induced hepatotoxicity after treatment of absence seizures, lithium (which is metabolized and excreted renally) should be considered instead.

B) INCORRECT:

Agranulocytosis is a potential side effect of carbamazepine and valproate, both of which may be used as long-term treatment for bipolar disorder. Carbamazepine can further cause aplastic anemia while valproate can lead to thrombocytopenia. Therefore, complete blood count (CBC) should be performed prior to and throughout pharmacotherapy. However, carbamazepine is considered an alternative agent, and given this patient's history of valproate-induced hepatotoxicity after treatment of absence seizures, lithium is preferred. Monitoring CBC is not necessary prior to or during lithium therapy.

C) CORRECT:

Lithium is the preferred long-term treatment of patients with bipolar disorder and those experiencing an acute manic episode. The use of lithium is limited by numerous adverse effects. For example, it can induce or worsen preexisting hypothyroidism by blocking the production and release of L-thyroxine. In addition, lithium is a teratogen and it is associated with an increased risk of congenital heart defects, such as Ebstein anomaly. Other adverse effects include lithium nephropathy, cardiotoxicity (e.g., T-wave depressions, sinus node dysfunction), and lithium-induced hyperparathyroidism, which can lead to hypercalcemia. Therefore, thyroid and kidney function as well as calcium levels should be assessed, and pregnancy should be ruled out prior to treatment. ECG should be obtained in patients with risk factors for atherosclerosis. Because lithium has a narrow therapeutic window, serum lithium concentrations should be closely monitored during treatment.

Lithium takes ∼ 5 days to achieve steady blood levels; therefore, an antipsychotic and/or benzodiazepine may be given as concomitant therapy in patients with an acute manic episode.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperprolactinemia is a potential side effect of second generation antipsychotics, which can be used as alternative agents in the long-term treatment of bipolar disorder. However, serum prolactin levels are obtained during rather than before treatment. Moreover, lithium is the preferred maintenance therapy option.

E) INCORRECT:

Metabolic side effects, such as dyslipidemia, are common in second generation antipsychotics, which can be used as alternative agents in the long-term treatment of bipolar disorder. However, lipid studies are obtained during rather than before treatment. Moreover, lithium is the preferred maintenance therapy for bipolar disorder.
questions.hint: This patient has an elevated mood, increased energy, affective lability, and pressured speech with flight of ideas, strongly suggesting an acute manic episode of bipolar disorder, for which long-term treatment with lithium is indicated.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up visit. She has a 2-year history of depressed mood and fatigue accompanied by early morning awakening. One week ago, she started feeling a decrease in her need for sleep and now feels rested after about 5 hours of sleep per night. She reports increased energy and libido. She had two similar episodes that occurred 6 months ago and a year ago, respectively. She has had a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss over the past month because she does not feel hungry. She enjoys her work as a librarian. She drinks two to three glasses of wine per week. Three months ago, she started using MDMA (ecstasy) occasionally at parties. On mental examination, she is alert and oriented to time and place; she appears irritable. She does not have auditory or visual hallucinations. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Certain substances, such as alcohol and amphetamines (e.g., MDMA), can cause symptoms of hypomania and mania. Although this patient occasionally uses MDMA, she had two periods of hypomanic symptoms prior to her use of the drug, making this diagnosis less likely. In addition, her moderate alcohol consumption is unlikely to cause substance-induced bipolar disorder.

B) INCORRECT:

Bipolar disorder with rapid cycling is characterized by ≥ 4 mood episodes in 1 year. This patient has had a total of 5 mood episodes in the past year (3 episodes of hypomania-like symptoms with 2 episodes of depressive symptoms in between). However, her symptoms do not fully meet the diagnostic criteria for mood episodes (i.e., hypomanic episode, manic episode, or major depressive episode), making another diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

The diagnostic criteria for delusional disorder require the presence of one or more delusions (e.g., grandeur, paranoia, persecution) lasting for ≥ 1 month that are not the result of schizophrenia. This patient does not have any features consistent with delusional disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with schizoaffective disorder can present with mood symptoms. A diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder requires the presence of psychotic symptoms that meet the criteria for schizophrenia along with features of a major mood episode (i.e., major depressive, manic, or mixed episode) lasting ≥ 2 weeks. This patient does not meet the criteria for schizoaffective disorder.

E) CORRECT:

Cyclothymic disorder (CD) is diagnosed in patients who experience numerous distinct periods of depressive symptoms that alternate with distinct periods of hypomanic symptoms for ≥ 2 years (or ≥ 1 year in children). Symptoms should not be absent for > 2 months nor fully meet the diagnostic criteria for major depressive, hypomanic, or manic episodes. This patient has had depressive symptoms for the past 2 years interspersed with 3 periods of hypomanic symptoms, which makes CD the most likely diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient has symptoms of hypomania (e.g., increased energy and libido, decreased need for sleep) and depression (e.g., depressed mood, fatigue, insomnia) but does not fully meet the criteria for a hypomanic episode, a manic episode, or a major depressive episode.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being detained by campus police for attempting to steal from the bookstore. Her roommate says that the patient has been acting strangely over the last 2 weeks. She has not slept in 4 days and has painted her room twice in that time span. She has also spent all of her savings on online shopping and lottery tickets. She has no history of psychiatric illness or substance abuse, and takes no medications. During the examination, she is uncooperative, combative, and refusing care. She screams, “Let me go, God has a plan for me and I must go finish it!”. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she describes her mood as “amazing.” She has a labile affect, speaks rapidly, and her thought process is tangential. She denies having any hallucinations. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clozapine, an antipsychotic, is used for treatment-resistant schizophrenia. Because of its potential adverse effect of agranulocytosis, it is reserved as maintenance therapy in patients with refractory schizophrenia and requires close monitoring. It is not used for treatment of bipolar disorder or acute mania.

B) INCORRECT:

Venlafaxine, a selective serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI), is commonly used in the treatment of major depressive disorder, anxiety, and panic disorder. It can actually worsen or trigger manic episodes, and should not be used in patients with a history of mania.

C) CORRECT:

Antipsychotics, e.g., haloperidol or risperidone, are the preferred initial treatment for an agitated and combative patient with acute mania. Their rapid onset and the possibility of intramuscular administration will allow for rapid sedation. A mood stabilizer should eventually be initiated and titrated for long-term maintenance therapy, but this will take a few days to take effect and she is in need of rapid stabilization at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Lithium, a mood stabilizer, is a first-line treatment option for bipolar affective disorder. It is effective in preventing both manic episodes and depression in bipolar patients when employed for long-term maintenance therapy. However, its oral route of administration, slower onset, and need for gradual titration makes it less useful as an initial therapy in an agitated patient with an acute manic episode.

E) INCORRECT:

Valproate, an anticonvulsant, is commonly used to treat bipolar disorder. Its mood-stabilizing effects make it a first-line choice for long-term maintenance treatment following an acute manic episode. However, its oral route of administration, slower onset, and need for gradual titration makes it less useful as an initial therapy in an agitated patient with an acute manic episode.

F) INCORRECT:

Sertraline, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), would be an appropriate initial treatment for major depressive disorder or anxiety, but is actually contraindicated for acute mania. In an acutely manic patient, any current antidepressants should be immediately discontinued as they may contribute to the manic episode.
questions.hint: This patient's history of elevated mood, reckless behavior, insomnia, pressured speech, and psychosis is consistent with an acute manic episode. Her uncooperative and combative behavior (severe agitation) will influence our choice of initial therapy.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with bipolar I disorder and hypertension comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of increased thirst, urinary frequency, and sleep disturbance. He says that he now drinks up to 30 cups of water daily. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. Examination shows decreased skin turgor. Serum studies show a sodium concentration of 149 mEq/L, a potassium concentration of 4.1 mEq/L, and an elevated antidiuretic hormone concentration. His urine osmolality is 121 mOsm/kg H2O. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Psychogenic polydipsia (PP) can occur during an acute bipolar psychosis and would present with polyuria, polydipsia, and low urine osmolality levels, all of which this patient has. However, water intoxication from PP would cause hyponatremia and low serum osmolality levels, due to the dilutional effects, and subsequently low ADH levels. Furthermore, patients with PP would not have features of dehydration (e.g., decreased skin turgor).

B) CORRECT:

Increased serum antidiuretic hormone (ADH) in a patient with features of diabetes insipidus is suggestive of a nephrogenic cause. Nephrogenic DI is the most common complication of long-term use of lithium, the first-line mood stabilizer for patients with bipolar disorder. Lithium is believed to cause nephrogenic DI by interfering with ADH signaling in the collecting duct cells, which results in reduced expression of water channel aquaporin-2 in these cells.
Image Description:

The binding of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) to V2 receptors (R) promotes the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels into the apical cell membranes of principal cells in the renal collecting duct, thereby facilitating free water reabsorption and concentration of urine.

In diabetes insipidus (DI), this mechanism is impaired either due to reduced pituitary ADH secretion (central DI) or defective renal ADH receptors (nephrogenic DI), in both cases reducing the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels. This impairs the ability of the kidneys to concentrate urine and results in the production of large amounts of dilute urine (up to 15 L/day).

C) INCORRECT:

Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) is synthesized in the hypothalamus and then transported to the posterior pituitary gland for secretion. Destruction of the posterior pituitary gland or the hypothalamic stalk by a large pituitary tumor can result in features of diabetes insipidus. However, this would lead to decreased ADH levels, indicating central diabetes insipidus, rather than increased ADH levels, suggesting nephrogenic DI, as seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's smoking history is a risk factor for both small cell lung cancer (SCLC) and squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lung. SCLC can cause high ADH levels due to SIADH, but patients with SIADH would have hyponatremia and a high urine osmolality. Polydipsia, polyuria, hypernatremia, and a low urine osmolality would not be expected. SCCs of the lung can secrete PTHrP, which can, in turn, result in hypercalcemia with subsequent neuropsychiatric disturbances and nephrogenic DI, which this patient has. However, the neuropsychiatric disturbance would usually be acute or subacute, unlike this patient's chronic psychiatric disorder. Moreover, this patient does not have a cough or a history of weight loss that would suggest a pulmonary malignancy.

E) INCORRECT:

A tumor in the adrenal cortex can cause primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn syndrome), which may lead to hypertension and, occasionally, mild hypernatremia (145–150 mEq/L). However, on its own, primary hyperaldosteronism would not cause polyuria, polydipsia, or features of dehydration such as decreased skin turgor. Hypokalemia caused by primary hyperaldosteronism can desensitize the renal tubules to ADH and, consequently, lead to mild nephrogenic DI, which this patient has. However, this patient's potassium levels are normal.
questions.hint: This patient has features of diabetes insipidus (DI): polyuria, polydipsia, dehydration, hypernatremia, and decreased urine osmolality (< 300 mOsmol/kg).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife for the evaluation of abnormal sleep patterns that began 10 days ago. She reports that he has only been sleeping 2–3 hours nightly during this time and has been jogging for long periods of the night on the treadmill. The patient has also been excessively talkative and has missed work on several occasions to write emails to his friends and relatives to convince them to invest in a new business idea that he has had. He has chronic kidney disease requiring hemodialysis, but he has refused to take his medications because he believes that he is cured. Eight months ago, he had a 3-week long period of persistent sadness and was diagnosed with major depressive disorder. Mental status examination shows psychomotor agitation and pressured speech. Treatment of this patient's condition should include which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant that is thought to act by increasing dopamine and norepinephrine levels via reuptake inhibition. It is indicated in the treatment of major depression, as adjunctive therapy in smoking cessation, and for seasonal affective disorder. However, bupropion should be avoided in patients with bipolar disorder because of its ability to precipitate or exacerbate a manic episode.

B) INCORRECT:

Triazolam is a benzodiazepine with a short duration of action. Benzodiazepines can be used as an adjunct in the treatment of acute manic episodes. However, benzodiazepines are primarily indicated for individuals with hypomania or mild to moderate manic episodes who cannot tolerate the first-line therapeutic combination. Moreover, the benzodiazepines found to be safe for such use are clonazepam and lorazepam rather than triazolam.

C) INCORRECT:

Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic that can be considered in patients with refractory mania who decline electroconvulsive therapy (ECT). However, because of its side effects, clozapine is not indicated as first-line therapy for bipolar disorder with an ongoing manic episode. Potentially serious adverse effects include agranulocytosis and other hematologic abnormalities, and metabolic syndrome. Other atypical antipsychotics (e.g., quetiapine, aripiprazole, olanzapine, risperidone) are indicated as an adjunct in the initial treatment for mania/hypomania.

D) CORRECT:

In individuals with bipolar disorder experiencing a severe manic episode, the recommended first-line therapy consists of a mood stabilizer combined with an antipsychotic. The mood stabilizers of choice are lithium and sodium valproate. In individuals with renal dysfunction, the use of lithium is contraindicated because the drug is eliminated by the kidneys, making sodium valproate the mood stabilizer of choice for this patient with chronic kidney disease.

The goal of acute treatment for a bipolar manic episode is the resolution of mania and psychosis. After stabilization, maintenance therapy is recommended to prevent future manic episodes.

E) INCORRECT:

Lithium is a first-line drug used in combination with an antipsychotic for treating manic episodes in individuals with bipolar disorder. Lithium is eliminated by the kidneys and has a narrow therapeutic index. An overdose may result in life-threatening lithium toxicity. Therefore, it is contraindicated in individuals with renal dysfunction, which is seen here.

F) INCORRECT:

Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant that acts by promoting serotonin and norepinephrine release. It is indicated in the treatment of major depression, generalized anxiety disorder, and tension-type headaches. However, atypical antidepressants are not indicated in treating individuals with bipolar disorder and an ongoing manic episode.

G) INCORRECT:

Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor that can be used in individuals with bipolar disorder who develop breakthrough depression while on maintenance therapy. However, because of their potential to induce mania or rapid cycling, antidepressants are best avoided in any individual with bipolar disorder who is not currently expressing depressive symptoms.
questions.hint: This patient's history and symptoms are consistent with bipolar I disorder with an acute manic episode.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband because of persistent sadness for the past 2 months. During this period, she also has had difficulty sleeping and an increased appetite. She had similar episodes that occurred 2 years ago and 9 months ago that each lasted for 4 months. Between these episodes, she reported feeling very energetic and rested after 3 hours of sleep. She often went for long periods of time without eating. She works as a stock market trader and received a promotion 5 months ago. She regularly attends yoga classes on the weekends with her friends. On mental status examination, she has a blunted affect. She denies suicidal thoughts and illicit drug use. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern
Major depressive disorder with atypical features

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern is characterized by ≥ 2 major depressive episodes over ≥ 2 years that are associated with a particular time of the year (e.g., the winter season). However, this patient's depressive symptoms do not fulfill the diagnostic criteria for a major depressive episode, and they are not associated with a particular season. In addition, the hypomanic symptoms seen in this patient are uncharacteristic of major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern.

B) INCORRECT:

Bipolar II disorder is characterized by ≥ 1 hypomanic episode and ≥ 1 major depressive episode. Although this patient has both hypomanic and depressive symptoms, her symptoms do not fulfill the diagnostic criteria for either a hypomanic episode (i.e., ≥ 3 hypomanic symptoms) or a major depressive episode. Moreover, the chronicity of her symptoms indicates a different diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Persistent depressive disorder (PDD) is a depressive disorder characterized by a depressed mood and ≥ 2 clinical features of PDD (feelings of hopelessness, low self-esteem, insomnia or hypersomnia, poor concentration or difficulty making decisions, fatigue, and an increase or decrease in appetite). These symptoms must be present during most of the day for the majority of the time over ≥ 2 years and cannot be attributable to substance use, bipolar disorder, psychotic disorders, or another medical condition. To meet the diagnostic criteria for PDD, there must be ≤ 2 consecutive months of a symptom-free period. This patient has had > 2 month periods without depressive symptoms. In addition, the hypomanic symptoms seen in this patient are uncharacteristic of PDD.

D) CORRECT:

Cyclothymic disorder (cyclothymia) is characterized by distinct periods of depressive symptoms and distinct periods of hypomanic symptoms for ≥ 2 years (or ≥ 1 year for children). To meet the diagnostic criteria for cyclothymic disorder, there must be ≤ 2 consecutive months of a symptom-free period, and symptoms should not meet the diagnostic criteria for either a hypomanic episode (i.e., ≥ 3 hypomanic symptoms) or a major depressive episode (i.e., ≥ 5 SIGECAPS symptoms).

E) INCORRECT:

Bipolar disorder with rapid cycling is characterized by ≥ 4 mood episodes within 1 year. Although this patient has had distinct episodes of hypomanic and depressive symptoms, her symptoms do not meet the diagnostic criteria for a mood episode (e.g., ≥ 3 hypomanic symptoms for a hypomanic episode, ≥ 5 SIGECAPS symptoms for a major depressive episode).

F) INCORRECT:

Major depressive disorder with atypical features is characterized by mood reactivity (i.e., transient improvement in mood in response to a positive event) and ≥ 2 symptoms of increased appetite or weight gain, hypersomnia, leaden paralysis, and long-standing interpersonal rejection sensitivity that results in occupational or social impairment. Although this patient has an increased appetite, she does not have other atypical features, and her symptoms do not meet the diagnostic criteria for a major depressive episode. In addition, the presence of hypomanic symptoms is uncharacteristic of major depressive disorder with atypical features.
questions.hint: This patient's depressive and hypomanic symptoms have not resulted in marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or required hospitalization.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her father because of irritability, mood swings, and difficulty sleeping over the past 10 days. A few days ago, she quit her job and spent all of her savings on supplies for a “genius business plan.” She has been energetic despite sleeping only 1–2 hours each night. She was diagnosed with major depressive disorder 2 years ago. Mental status examination shows pressured speech, a labile affect, and flight of ideas. Throughout the examination, she repeatedly states “I feel great, I don't need to be here.” Urine toxicology screening is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Delusional disorder is characterized by at least one delusion that lasts for at least 1 month but does not cause significant functional impairment. This patient has experienced significant functional impairment as part of a manic episode for the last 10 days, but no delusions, making a different diagnosis more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Cyclothymic disorder is characterized by short hypomanic and mild depressive episodes over a period of at least 2 years. To diagnose the condition, the hypomanic episode must be shorter than 1 week and the depressive episodes must be shorter than 2 weeks. This patient has experienced significant functional impairment as part of a manic episode for the past 10 days, making a different diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Bipolar II disorder is characterized by the occurrence of at least one hypomanic episode and at least one major depressive episode. To diagnose the condition, the hypomanic episode must last for at least 4 consecutive days and may not impair functioning or necessitate hospitalization. This patient has experienced significant functional impairment as part of a manic episode for the past 10 days, making a different diagnosis more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Depression with atypical features is characterized by depressive episodes accompanied by mood reactivity, hyperphagia, hypersomnia, and/or interpersonal rejection sensitivity. This patient has experienced significant functional impairment as part of a manic episode without atypical features, making a different diagnosis more likely.

E) CORRECT:

Bipolar I disorder is a mood disorder characterized by the occurrence of ≥ 1 manic episodes with or without depressive episodes. In order to diagnose bipolar I disorder, these manic episodes must last for at least 7 consecutive days, and patients must have at least 3 of the DIG FAST changes (distractibility, impulsive behavior, grandiosity, flight of ideas, activity increase, sleep deficit, and talkativeness). These changes cannot be attributable to an organic psychic disorder or psychotropic substances.

F) INCORRECT:

Schizoaffective disorder is characterized by psychosis (e.g., hallucinations, delusions) that is intermittently accompanied by a major mood disorder (e.g., manic or depressive symptoms). To diagnose the condition, the psychotic symptoms must have been present for at least 2 weeks in the absence of any mood disturbance. This patient does not have any signs of psychosis, making a different diagnosis more likely.

G) INCORRECT:

ADHD is characterized by impulsivity, hyperactivity, and inattention that results in impairment of social skills and occupational or academic performance. Symptoms usually first appear before the age of 12 and must be present for at least 6 months in order for the condition to be diagnosed. Symptoms must occur in more than one setting (e.g., at school and at home). This patient has experienced significant functional impairment as part of a manic episode for the past 10 days and has a history of depression, making a different diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: This patient exhibits significant changes in mood, energy, activity, and sleep that has led to severe functional impairment.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man is brought to the physician by his girlfriend for evaluation of abnormal behavior that began 10 days ago. The patient was arrested by the police after he was found running naked in the streets at night and talking to his “fellow prophets.” His girlfriend reports that he has not slept for over a week, although he reports feeling “great and refreshed.” She says that he recently disrupted a family wedding by announcing that he had invested all his and his girlfriend's money in shares of a spacecraft company in order to fund his presidential campaign. The patient's girlfriend also says that he has been overly active for the last 10 days, constantly walking back and forth and talking with sweeping gesticulations. Three weeks ago, his mother died from a ruptured cerebral aneurysm. He has a history of major depressive disorder but has not had a depressive episode for more than a year. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, his speech is pressured, he is easily distractible, and he tells many anecdotes. Results of a complete blood count, serum electrolyte concentrations, and liver enzyme activities show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Major depressive disorder with atypical features
Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Schizoaffective disorder is characterized by psychosis (e.g., hallucinations, delusions) that is intermittently accompanied by a major mood disorder (e.g., manic or depressive symptoms). To diagnose this condition, the psychotic symptoms must be more dominant than the mood symptoms, and psychosis must be present for at least 2 weeks in the absence of any mood disturbance. In this patient, auditory hallucinations (as suggested by his talking to his “fellow prophets”) have been present for less than 2 weeks and there was no period during which psychosis was not accompanied by symptoms of mania.

B) INCORRECT:

Pathological grief is characterized by functional impairment in response to the death of a loved one and yearning for the deceased that persists beyond 12 months in adults or 6 months in children. It can be associated with hallucinations of the deceased and somatic symptoms. This patient has experienced the death of his mother, but his mood and behavior disturbances are not described as yearning, and they do not meet the clinical timeframe for pathological grief.

C) INCORRECT:

Major depressive disorder with atypical features is characterized by mood reactivity (i.e., transient improvement in mood in response to a positive event) and ≥ 2 of the following symptoms: increased appetite, weight gain, hypersomnia, leaden paralysis, and/or long-standing interpersonal rejection sensitivity that results in occupational or social impairment. Although this patient has a history of major depressive disorder, he does not have other atypical features, and he is experiencing a manic episode.

D) INCORRECT:

Bipolar II disorder is characterized by ≥ 1 hypomanic episode and ≥ 1 major depressive episode. Although this patient has a history of major depressive episodes, his current manic symptoms are more severe than hypomania and meet the diagnostic criteria of a manic episode, as they have led to significant functional impairment.

E) CORRECT:

Bipolar I disorder is a subtype of bipolar disorder that is characterized by at least one manic episode lasting ≥ 1 week with or without major depressive episodes. In addition to meeting the criteria for a manic episode, this patient has a history of major depressive disorder, which is supportive of bipolar I disorder, though not necessary for the diagnosis. In bipolar I disorder, mood changes may be accompanied by mood-congruent psychotic symptoms, as seen in this patient (auditory hallucinations as suggested by his talking to the “fellow prophets”). Any stressor (e.g., the death of the patient's mother) can trigger a mood episode (e.g., mania, major depressive episode) in bipolar I disorder. An acute manic episode is a psychiatric emergency and requires immediate management, including assessment of suicidal behavior and treatment with a mood stabilizer and/or an atypical antipsychotic, depending on the severity of the manic episode.

To remember the features of a manic episode, think “DIG FAST”: D = Distractibility, I = Irresponsibility, G = Grandiosity, F = Flight of ideas, A = Activity increase, S = Sleep deficit, T = Talkativeness.

F) INCORRECT:

Cyclothymic disorder (cyclothymia) is characterized by ≥ 2 years of distinct periods of depressive symptoms that do not meet the diagnostic criteria of a major depressive episode and distinct periods of hypomanic symptoms that do not meet the diagnostic criteria of a hypomanic episode. Any symptom-free period in cyclothymia must last less than 2 months. This patient has a history of major depressive disorder, indicating that his depressive symptoms did meet the criteria for a major depressive episode, and his symptom-free period lasted for more than 2 months (over a year). Furthermore, his current symptoms are not hypomanic, but meet the diagnostic criteria of a full manic episode.

G) INCORRECT:

Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by ≥ 1 positive symptom(s) of psychosis (hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech, grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior) lasting < 1 month and often develops after stressful life events. This patient likely has auditory hallucinations (as suggested by his talking to his “fellow prophets”) and his symptoms developed after a stressful life event (his mother's death). However, he also experiences mood disturbances (i.e., elevated mood) and meets the criteria for a manic episode, which suggests a different diagnosis.

H) INCORRECT:

Major depressive disorder (MDD) with psychotic features is characterized by MDD and concurrent psychotic symptoms that are often mood congruent (hallucinations or delusions about, e.g., deserved punishment, death, or worthlessness). Although this patient has a history of major depressive disorder, he is currently experiencing a manic episode, which is a criterion of exclusion for MDD. In addition, his psychotic symptoms are mood congruent with mania rather than with a major depressive episode.
questions.hint: This patient with an abnormally elevated mood meets the criteria for a manic episode: ≥ 7 days of significant functional impairment in combination with distractibility, irresponsible behavior, grandiosity, activity increase, sleep deficit, and talkativeness.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man presents for care accompanied by his wife. Normally quiet and mild-mannered, he paces around the room, talking rapidly and loudly about how good he feels and about his new ability to predict the future. He wants to “spread the word” about his new powers. His wife indicates that he has been sleeping only 2 or 3 hours per night, has been missing work, and has spent a good deal of the couple’s savings since his behavior changed approximately 6 weeks ago.
He has no history of mental illness or substance use, but he has a family history of depression. Routine physical examination and laboratory findings are normal.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Schizophrenia is a chronic and usually severe mental disorder. People with this disorder may have a variety of psychotic symptoms, disorganized behavior, a reduction in emotional expression, and functional impairments. Mood symptoms may occur but are not prominent.

B) CORRECT:

Bipolar I disorder is the most likely diagnosis in a patient who is having a manic episode and has no history of depressive episodes.

For a diagnosis of bipolar I disorder, a patient must have experienced at least one manic episode. During a manic episode, a person has elevated, expansive, or irritable mood along with at least three or four of the following symptoms: inflated self-esteem or grandiosity, decreased need for sleep, pronounced talkativeness or pressured speech, flight of ideas or racing thoughts, increased activity or agitation, and behavior that is likely to have painful consequences. Symptoms are severe enough to cause impaired functioning.

This patient fits this diagnosis because he has expansive mood and is agitated, talkative, and grandiose. His consequent poor judgment has led him to spend an inappropriate portion of the couple’s savings. Further supporting the diagnosis is a family history of a mood disorder (depression) and the absence of other causes of a mental status change, such as substance use or a nonpsychiatric illness.

The absence of depressive symptoms in this patient is consistent with a diagnosis of bipolar disorder. Depressive episodes are common in bipolar I disorder but are not required for the diagnosis. In fact, patients with bipolar I disorder may never have a major depressive episode. During a major depressive episode, a person will have distinctly depressed mood and may have trouble taking pleasure in most activities (anhedonia); several neurovegetative symptoms of depression will also be present.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with no prior psychiatric history who presents with 6 weeks of rapid speech, grandiosity, decreased need for sleep, increased goal-directed activity, agitation, and functional impairment is bipolar I disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

Major depressive disorder is diagnosed when a patient has had at least one major depressive episode but has never had a manic or hypomanic episode.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with bipolar II disorder have never had a manic episode but have experienced both a hypomanic episode and a major depressive episode. A hypomanic episode is less severe than a manic episode, but the two entities have many symptoms in common. The chief distinction is that, during a hypomanic episode, although there is an observable change from the person’s usual level of functioning, he or she can carry on day to day without requiring hospitalization.

E) INCORRECT:

Delusional disorder is characterized by delusions (false, fixed beliefs) that have lasted at least one month, do not have the disorganization and negative symptoms characteristic of schizophrenia, and do not have a prominent mood component. Individuals with delusional disorder continue to function without impairment, and they are not usually perceived as odd or bizarre.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man with a history of bipolar disorder reports 2 weeks of depressed mood, fatigue, excess sleeping and eating, and a lack of interest in things that were once pleasurable. He had two manic episodes, spaced years apart, while he was in his twenties. He does not remember much detail about how those episodes were treated, but he does recall taking lithium as part of the treatment. He stopped all psychiatric treatment at least 3 years ago. This is his first episode of depression.
Which one of the following medications is the best treatment for this patient’s depression?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antidepressants, including venlafaxine, are usually avoided as a first-line monotherapy for bipolar depression.

B) CORRECT:

Manic episodes are the cardinal feature of bipolar disorder, but there is evidence that depression is the greater cause of morbidity and poor functioning in this illness. Bipolar depression poses a significant treatment challenge because antidepressant medications can cause a person with bipolar disorder to become manic, a phenomenon known as “switching.”

As recently as the 1990s, bipolar depression was typically managed by first “covering” the patient with a mood stabilizer (typically lithium carbonate at therapeutic doses) and then adding an antidepressant to treat depression symptoms. Unfortunately, research to date has not proven the benefit of this approach. There is scant evidence that traditional antidepressant medications are effective for the treatment of bipolar depression. In fact, it has been hard to prove the efficacy of many bipolar depression treatments; there are many more evidence-based treatments for mania.

This patient has had relatively few episodes of acute illness. His manic episodes are further in the past, and he has managed without psychotropic medication for several years. The prudent approach now is to attempt treatment with a single agent (monotherapy).

The antipsychotic quetiapine is one monotherapy that has demonstrated efficacy in treating bipolar depression. The FDA approved it for this indication in 2008. A second antipsychotic, lurasidone, was approved for bipolar depression in 2013.

Although quetiapine’s efficacy has been demonstrated and the drug has regulatory approval, many patients do not respond to this treatment. All existing treatments for bipolar depression are only partially effective. Thus, in practice, numerous medication combinations may be tried in an effort to provide relief to patients who are left with residual symptoms. Medications such as lithium, antipsychotics, and antiepileptic drugs are commonly employed. When symptoms persist, antidepressants sometimes find their way back into the mix, but they are prescribed with caution.

Key learning point: An appropriate monotherapy for bipolar depression is quetiapine.

C) INCORRECT:

Lithium is still the mainstay for treating mania and for long-term maintenance in bipolar disorder. It also appears to reduce the risk of suicide over time. It compares unfavorably to quetiapine in the treatment of bipolar depression.

D) INCORRECT:

Other antipsychotics, such as olanzapine, risperidone, and ziprasidone, do not appear to have the same antidepressant effects as quetiapine and lurasidone. (Research, however, supports the combination of olanzapine and fluoxetine as a treatment for bipolar depression.)

E) INCORRECT:

Antidepressants, including bupropion, are usually avoided as a first-line monotherapy for bipolar depression.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by relatives who are concerned about her behavior. During the past 2 weeks, she has become grandiose (claiming that she is president of the universe) and has been staying up all night to rearrange furniture. She has also been making extravagant, unnecessary purchases with her credit cards and annoying neighbors with loud rants.
During the interview, she speaks rapidly, is dismissive of staff, and is combative when redirected. Her physical examination and laboratory tests (including CT of the head, electrolyte levels, and leukocyte count) are all within normal limits; she required lorazepam intravenously to tolerate the head CT. She takes no prescribed medications; there is no known use of alternative medicines or illicit substances.
Her family notes that she behaved in a similar fashion 30 years ago, after the birth of her son. Family members are willing to help her follow an outpatient treatment plan.
Which one of the following therapies is the best first-line treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acute mania is a psychiatric emergency characterized by decreased need for sleep; fast speech; racing thoughts; an elevated, expansive, or irritable mood; increased activity or agitation; and injudicious behavior that is likely to cause painful consequences. Symptoms are severe enough to cause impaired functioning.

Nearly all antipsychotic drugs and many mood stabilizers (e.g., lithium, anticonvulsants) are effective treatments for manic symptoms. Lithium is the best established medication available for management of mania, and its ability to reduce suicide risk is an advantage. Antipsychotics like olanzapine may have a more rapid onset than lithium and anticonvulsants. They may help with symptom control in the early phases of treatment. The combination of lithium and an antipsychotic is more efficacious than monotherapy.

Treatment adherence is a challenge for patients during a manic episode, but supportive family can help a patient manage outpatient treatment and avoid a psychiatric hospitalization. As long as the patient has family support to manage dosing and the need for periodic measurement of lithium levels, a lithium-olanzapine combination is the best first choice.

Key learning point: In the outpatient setting, acute stabilization of mania is best achieved by prescribing a combination of lithium and an antipsychotic medication, such as olanzapine.

B) INCORRECT:

Antidepressants such as venlafaxine can precipitate or worsen mania and should be avoided.

C) INCORRECT:

Alprazolam is a benzodiazepine and can provide added sedation for a patient with mania, but it will not treat psychosis or other core symptoms of mania.

D) INCORRECT:

Lithium and valproate can each play a role in the treatment of acute mania. They would not, however, be prescribed in combination during an acute manic episode.

E) INCORRECT:

Lamotrigine is a mood stabilizer often prescribed for bipolar depression, but it has no established efficacy in treating acute mania. Furthermore, the risk of serious rash, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, and toxic epidermal necrolysis make lamotrigine an inappropriate first-treatment choice.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman reports that she has started dating again since her divorce. Speaking rapidly, she describes meeting male partners through an online dating service, feeling “supremely” confident, and enjoying a “new perspective” on life. A friend, who was concerned about her distinctly different thinking and behavior, urged her to see her doctor and accompanies her to the appointment.
On further inquiry, the patient says she has engaged in vaginal intercourse without condoms with seven male partners during the past 2 weeks and says that she feels as if “a rush came over her.” She does not know the HIV status of these partners, but she dismisses concerns about their HIV status. She doesn't want them to use a condom because that would interfere with her "new spirit."
She says her mood is terrific, and the increased confidence has given her great energy despite sleeping only 1 to 2 hours per night. The friend suspects that the patient may not be sleeping at all as she is receiving voicemail and text messages from her at all hours.
The patient seems unwilling to discuss her sexual behavior further and changes the topic to describe several new repair projects that she has started around the house and the expensive, new furniture that she recently bought. She lives alone, on assets received through her divorce settlement, and is not employed. Her parents are both deceased. She has one child, an adult daughter who lives in another city. The friend took off work to accompany the patient to the appointment.
Both a urine drug test and a rapid HIV test are negative. She reports no thoughts of harming herself or others.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient's care?

choices.text: Provide and encourage consistent use of condoms
Recommend hospital admission for treatment of her condition
Provide a script for her to rehearse to help her inquire about the HIV status of her sexual partners
Provide a prescription for HIV postexposure prophylaxis to be initiated within 72 hours of sexual intercourse without a condom
Use motivational interviewing to help her change her disinhibited sexual behaviors

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If the mania remains untreated, encouraging the patient to use condoms and to inquire about her partners' HIV status is unlikely to reduce her disinhibited sexual behaviors, nor will motivational interviewing be effective.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has acute mania, which is defined by the presence of elevated, expansive, or irritable mood plus at least three of the following symptoms: inflated self-esteem, reduced need for sleep, increased pressure to talk, racing thoughts or distractibility, and excessive involvement in behaviors that carry a high risk for negative outcomes (eg, extravagant shopping, sexual adventures, or improbable commercial schemes).

The most appropriate intervention for reducing high-risk behaviors during a period of acute mania is inpatient psychiatric hospitalization. The goal is to stabilize the patient with medications in a safe setting. Although many patients refuse voluntary hospitalization in these circumstances, a surprising number of patients do accept a recommendation for treatment in the hospital.

If a patient refuses hospitalization, it may be possible to admit her to the hospital involuntarily if she meets the criteria for emergency commitment where she lives. Every state has its own rules governing emergency commitment. Health care providers should familiarize themselves with local statutes.

Medical judgments about emergency commitment (involuntary hospitalization) are guided by competing ethical values. On one side, a physician is concerned about the patient's welfare and safety, the desire to relieve the patient's potential suffering, and concern for the welfare and safety of people potentially affected by the patient. On the other hand, doctors are obliged to respect the patient's right to autonomy and privacy. Physicians should also appreciate the limits of being able to predict what a patient may do in the future.

If hospitalization is not feasible, one can try to initiate treatment for acute mania as an outpatient. Treatment adherence is likely to be limited. The clinician may try to meet frequently with the patient. If her symptoms worsen, hospitalization may then be possible. Supportive family or friends may help if the patient consents to involve them.

Key learning point: The most appropriate intervention for reducing disinhibited sexual behaviors in an acutely manic patient is to initiate treatment for acute mania, in the hospital if possible.

C) INCORRECT:

If the mania remains untreated, encouraging the patient to use condoms and to inquire about her partners' HIV status is unlikely to reduce her disinhibited sexual behaviors, nor will motivational interviewing be effective.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients who have mania are unlikely to be able to comply with postexposure prophylaxis.

E) INCORRECT:

If the mania remains untreated, encouraging the patient to use condoms and to inquire about her partners' HIV status is unlikely to reduce her disinhibited sexual behaviors, nor will motivational interviewing be effective.

questions.text:
A young woman with a history of bipolar disorder treated with lithium is brought to the emergency department by friends after an argument at a bar. Her friends report that she was drinking alcohol earlier that night and has been behaving erratically for the past several days.
The patient is talkative, has pressured speech, and is distracted. She is furious about being brought to the emergency department and threatens to kill the friends who brought her. She seems to be internally preoccupied and occasionally shrieks without provocation.
On examination, she is afebrile, with a blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg and a heart rate of 80 beats per minute. Her heart monitor is unremarkable. She becomes increasingly agitated as her blood is about to be drawn, and she is subsequently placed in restraints.
Laboratory evaluation reveals a lithium level of <0.05 mEq/liter (therapeutic range, 0.6–1.2) and an alcohol level of 300 mg/dL (>400 mg/dL is potentially fatal).
Which one of the following interventions is the most appropriate next step for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lithium alone is not an effective approach to treating severe mania. Although restarting lithium may be reasonable for this patient at some future point, the earliest time to start it would be after the alcohol intoxication has passed. Before restarting lithium, the clinician should explore why the patient stopped taking the medication in the first place and evaluate whether it is still the best option for her. Also, a more complete history of her substance use can be sought once she is no longer intoxicated.

B) INCORRECT:

In acute mania, benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam, are often added to relieve anxiety and agitation, but in the context of alcohol intoxication, it is advisable to forego this option. Similarly, one would not offer chlordiazepoxide while the patient has alcohol intoxication, although it may be a reasonable option for alcohol withdrawal symptoms if the patient were to develop such symptoms later in her course.

C) INCORRECT:

The antipsychotic chlorpromazine tends to have more adverse effects than haloperidol and is not routinely recommended to manage acute mania.

D) CORRECT:

This patient, although intoxicated with alcohol, is also displaying signs of mania, including pressured speech, irritability, aggressive behavior, and hallucinations. She is making homicidal statements and is agitated, requiring urgent treatment. The most appropriate choice for treatment in the acute phase is intravenous haloperidol — or intramuscular haloperidol if it is not possible to place an intravenous line. This medication will have rapid onset while posing relatively little risk. During administration, the patient should be monitored for arrhythmia on a heart monitor.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for a patient with severe acute mania is an antipsychotic, such as haloperidol.

E) INCORRECT:

Activated charcoal would have no effect in the setting of alcohol ingestion.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the office by her father because of irritability, mood swings, and difficulty sleeping over the past 10 days. A few days ago, she quit her job and spent all of her savings on supplies for a “genius business plan.” She has been energetic despite sleeping only 1–2 hours each night. She was diagnosed with major depressive disorder 2 years ago. Mental status examination shows pressured speech, a labile affect, and flight of ideas. Urine toxicology screening is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cyclothymic disorder is characterized by short hypomanic and mild depressive episodes over a period of at least 2 years. To diagnose the condition, the hypomanic episode must be shorter than 1 week and the depressive episodes must be shorter than 2 weeks. This patient has experienced significant functional impairment as part of a manic episode for the past 10 days, making a different diagnosis more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Bipolar II disorder is characterized by the occurrence of at least one hypomanic episode and at least one major depressive episode. To diagnose the condition, the hypomanic episode must last for at least 4 consecutive days and may not impair functioning or necessitate hospitalization. This patient has experienced significant functional impairment as part of a manic episode for the past 10 days, making a different diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Depression with atypical features is characterized by depressive episodes accompanied by mood reactivity, hyperphagia, hypersomnia, and/or interpersonal rejection sensitivity. This patient has experienced significant functional impairment as part of a manic episode without atypical features, making a different diagnosis more likely.

D) CORRECT:

Bipolar I disorder is a mood disorder characterized by the occurrence of ≥ 1 manic episodes with or without depressive episodes. In order to diagnose bipolar I disorder, these manic episodes must last for at least 7 consecutive days, and patients must have at least 3 of the DIG FAST changes (distractibility, impulsive behavior, grandiosity, flight of ideas, activity increase, sleep deficit, and talkativeness). These changes cannot be attributable to an organic psychic disorder or psychotropic substances.

E) INCORRECT:

Schizoaffective disorder is characterized by psychosis (e.g., hallucinations, delusions) that is intermittently accompanied by a major mood disorder (e.g., manic or depressive symptoms). To diagnose the condition, the psychotic symptoms must have been present for at least 2 weeks in the absence of any mood disturbance. This patient does not have any signs of psychosis, making a different diagnosis more likely.
